Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story:
I could feel my phone buzzing in my pocket as I pulled up to the next address, the package for apartment 3B balanced on my arm. My girlfriend’s name flashed on the screen, her texts coming in rapid succession—each one sharper than the last. Our argument from last night had spiraled out of control, and now she was threatening to end things if I didn’t call her back and talk it through. My chest tightened. I knew she expected me to drop everything, to be the boyfriend who could fix things, who would listen and make it right.

But I was on the clock, and the customer was already waiting at the door, arms crossed, eyeing the package. Company policy was clear: I needed to get a signature for anything over fifty dollars, no exceptions. If I left the package unattended or rushed the process, I could get written up—or worse. My girlfriend’s words echoed in my head, but so did my supervisor’s warnings. I stood there, torn, the phone vibrating in my hand, the customer impatient, and my heart pulled in two directions, unsure which role to answer first.
